channel.title: Middle East – Baraza
channel.description: Critical Collaboration on the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa

item.title: Game-Changer: The Rise and Expansion of the Global University
item.dc:creator: Bradley Williams
item.description: There is a de facto 21st century gold rush among elite universities in the United States. In the age of globalized capital, privatization of the state, and commodified education, top-ranked, private universities and colleges are expanding beyond U.S. borders and building proxy campuses in locations fundamental to American economic and military interests. Of the U.S. … Continue reading Game-Changer: The Rise and Expansion of the Global University →

item.title: Imperial Flush: Crane Co. Valves in Yemen and Saudi Arabia
item.dc:creator: Cristina Violante
item.description: In America today, showering daily is a social norm. We avoid body odor, grease, and sweat, and consider such qualities unhygienic or “gross.” We also consider the technologies behind the daily shower – bathrooms, sewers, and heating systems – and the parts that construct them – valves and pipes – to be commonplace. Their omnipresence … Continue reading Imperial Flush: Crane Co. Valves in Yemen and Saudi Arabia →

item.title: Between Miracle and Afterthought: Hebrew in MESAAS
item.dc:creator: Aviv Becher
item.description: My parents, native Israelis with wide and deep ties to the Hebrew language, insisted, always, on maintaining a Hebrew-speaking household in the U.S. so that my two sisters and I might carry on in the world with “a miracle” of a language at our disposal. I remember my father telling me excitedly that, “before 1948, … Continue reading Between Miracle and Afterthought: Hebrew in MESAAS →

item.title: Sketch of a Literary Scene
item.dc:creator: Max Shmookler
item.description: The stories in our collection span the roughly four decades since the publication of Tayyib Salih’s much acclaimed Season of Migration to the North in 1969. Some are works of social protest, others of technical mastery or experimental daring. Despite variations in theme and style, we’ve chosen them because they all revolve around Khartoum in one … Continue reading Sketch of a Literary Scene →

item.title: Modeling the Collective Hero: An Interview with Egyptian Playwright Ibrahim El-Husseiny
item.dc:creator: Hani Omer
item.description: Ibrahim El-Husseiny wrote the play “Comedy of Sorrows” only a few months after Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak’s resignation in February of 2011.  As such, it was one of the very first creative pieces produced in response to the Egyptian revolution.  Following a run of 60 performances in Egypt, a translation by Rebekah Maggor toured the States … Continue reading Modeling the Collective Hero: An Interview with Egyptian Playwright Ibrahim El-Husseiny →
